Talking about probability is talking about assigning a value to some elements of sets, or to some subsets of sets.

A outcome is an element. Outcomes must be mutually exclusive. No two outcomes can happen at the same time.
An event is a subset with outcomes as its elements.

Both the value and the sets must fulfill some conditions to allow this assignment to be without contradictions:

  • The set of all possible outcomes Ω\OmegaΩ can be whatever set.
  • The set of all event FFF must form a σ\sigmaσ-algebra.
  • The probability is a measure that assigns to each event E∈FE\in FE∈F its probability value P(E)P(E)P(E) (or Pr(E)Pr(E)Pr(E))
  • It is a convention that P(Ω)=1P(\Omega)=1P(Ω)=1
  • For general uncountable sets, we need specific σ\sigmaσ-algebra called the Borel algebra

We assign probabilities to events. A single outcome can be an event.

For all events, their probabilities are non-negative values.

The probability of an event AAA happening or event BBB happening (the probability of situation where at least one happens) is the sum of their respective probabilities.

It is important to distinguish between colloquial naming and mathematical definitions.

Example

Let Ω\OmegaΩ be the set of outcomes:

  • AAA and name it: It rains and the grass is wet
  • BBB and name it: It rains and the grass is not wet
  • CCC and name it: It doesn't rain and the grass is wet
  • DDD and name it: It doesn't rain the grass is not wet

Let FFF be the set of events:

  • It rains: a subset of A,BA, BA,B
  • It doesn't rain: a subset of C,DC, DC,D
  • The grass is wet: a subset of A,CA, CA,C
  • The grass is not wet: a subset of B,DB, DB,D
  • Plus the four above
